author: @statquest
text: Corrections: 8:53 I meant to say "the remaining 198.7 people without the mutated gene". 14:27 I correctly wrote "If the tests worked as expected, 5% should have p-values less than 0.05". That is correct. However, when recording the voiceover, I said "5% should have p-values less than 0.5", which is not correct.  NOTE: In statistics, machine learning and computer programming, the default base for the log() function is 'e'. Thus, throughout this video I use the natural logarithm, or log base 'e', to do the calculations.  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @anshulk302
text: # Possible R code corresponding to video (there might be mistakes or better ways to do it!)  # Load data cancerData <- data.frame(hasCancer = factor(c(rep("yes",29),rep("no",327)), levels = c("yes","no")), hasMutatedGene = factor(c(rep("yes",23),rep("no",6),rep("yes",117),rep("no",210)), levels = c("yes","no")))  # See table t <- with(cancerData, table(hasMutatedGene,hasCancer)) t  # Calculate odds ratio OR = (23/117)/(6/210) OR  # Fisher's Exact Test fisher.test(t)  # Chi-Square Test chisq.test(t)  # The Wald Test (using logistic regression) cancerData$hasCancer <- relevel(cancerData$hasCancer, ref = "no") # code yes=1 and no=0 cancerData$hasMutatedGene <- relevel(cancerData$hasMutatedGene, ref = "no") # code yes=1 and no=0 summary(logit <- glm(hasCancer~hasMutatedGene, data = cancerData, family="binomial")) exp(logit$coefficients[2])  # Alternate display of logistic regression result if(!require(jtools)) install.packages("jtools") library(jtools) summ(logit, exp=TRUE)

author: @MrCk0212
text: Here is the code in Python to generate the histogram at 10:10.  But one thing I would like to raise is that it seems not necessary to have random sample size as you can notice that it would be cancelled out when calculating the odd ratios.  import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt  n = 1000000 sample_size = np.random.rand(n)*100+300 #Sample size ~ uniform disturbution between 300 and 400 p1 = np.random.rand(n) #p1 = proability with cancer ~ uniform distribution between 0 and 1 p2 = np.random.rand(n) #p2 = probability with gene mutation ~ uniform distribution between 0 and 1 odd_ratios = (sample_size*p1*p2 / sample_size*(1-p1)*p2) / (sample_size*p1*(1-p2) / sample_size*(1-p1)*(1-p2)) log_odd_ratios = np.log(odd_ratios)  plt.hist(log_odd_ratios,bins=np.arange(-10,10.5,0.5))

text: 3:45 The odd of having cancer  Odd ratio =  The odd of having cancer, with mutated genes /  The odd of having cancer without mutated genes  4:45 "larger value of ratio of MUTATED-havecancer-odd vs NOTMUTATED-havecancer-odd means mutated gene is a good predictor of cancer".  And vice versa:  Larger value of ratio of mutated-HAVECANCER-odd vs mutated-HAVENOCANCER-odd means CANCER is a good predictor of MUTATED.  Both odd ratios are the same: 6.88.  How significant is the ratio of the odds? Test it with: 1) Fisher, 2) Chi Square, or 3) Wald

author: @Anpa940
text: I don't understand the standard deviation in the example. The log(odds ratio) stays the same regardless of the sample size, as the ratio stays the same, but the standard deviation does change with the sample size. Consider that you multiply all the above numbers by 100. 2300 cancer&mutant, 600 cancer&no_mutant, 11700 no_cancer&mutant, 21000 no_cancer&no_mutant. The odds ratio stays the same. (2300/11700) / (600/21000) = 6.88. However, the standard deviation goes from 0.47 to 0.047, which would indicated that we are 41 standard deviations away from the mean (=log(6.88)/0.047)?

author: @yarikd1444
text: Hey, below is python code for log odds distribution with these particular numbers from the video (cancer & gene) and calculating p_value counts for all 3 tests:  import warnings import numpy as np import pandas as pd from scipy.stats import norm from scipy.stats import fisher_exact from scipy.stats import chi2_contingency  warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')  def cancer_log_odds(n_iter):      log_odds = []     wald_p_values = []     fisher_exact_p_values = []     chi2_p_values = []      for i in range(n_iter):         sample_size = np.random.randint(300, 400)          cancer_array = pd.Series(np.random.rand(1, sample_size)[0])         gene_array = pd.Series(np.random.rand(1, sample_size)[0])          cancer_binary = cancer_array.map(lambda x: 1 if x < 0.08 else 0)         gene_binary = gene_array.map(lambda x: 1 if x < 0.39 else 0)          cr = pd.crosstab(gene_binary, cancer_binary, rownames=['gene'], colnames=['cancer'])          odds_0 = cr.iloc[0, 1] / cr.iloc[0, 0]         odds_1 = cr.iloc[1, 1] / cr.iloc[1, 0]         log_odds_ratio = np.log(odds_0/odds_1)          if log_odds_ratio != np.inf:             log_odds.append(log_odds_ratio)          # wald test         wald_std = np.sqrt(1/cr.iloc[0, 0] + 1/cr.iloc[0, 1] + 1/cr.iloc[1, 0] + 1/cr.iloc[1, 1])         z_score = log_odds_ratio / wald_std         wald_p = (1 - norm.cdf(abs(z_score)))*2          wald_p_values.append(wald_p)                  # fisher exact          fisher_exact_p_values.append(fisher_exact(cr)[1])                  # chi squared         chi2_p_values.append(chi2_contingency(cr)[1])          wald = pd.Series(wald_p_values).map(lambda x:1 if x < 0.05 else 0)     wald_value_counts = wald.value_counts(normalize=True)          fisher = pd.Series(fisher_exact_p_values).map(lambda x:1 if x < 0.05 else 0)     fisher_value_counts = fisher.value_counts(normalize=True)      chi2 = pd.Series(chi2_p_values).map(lambda x:1 if x < 0.05 else 0)     chi2_value_counts = chi2.value_counts(normalize=True)          sns.displot(log_odds);          return wald_value_counts, fisher_value_counts, chi2_value_counts, log_odds  wald_value_counts, fisher_value_counts, chi2_value_counts, log_odds_ = cancer_log_odds(10000) wald_value_counts[1], fisher_value_counts[1], chi2_value_counts[1]

author: @mostinho7
text: Odds of something is itself a ratio (probability of it happening/probability of it not happening) The odds are usually odds of x given y (in this case the odds of getting cancer given that you do have a gene)  Log odds ratio is a ratio of ratios (ratio of the log odds) but the given condition changes. This tells us if the â€œgivenâ€ condition has an effect on the odds of x happening.  Example: 3:40 Log odds ratio = (log odds of getting cancer | you have the gene) / (log odds of getting cancer | you donâ€™t have the gene) This can tell us the effect of the given condition (given you have the gene vs given you donâ€™t have the gene) on the odds of x happening (cancer vs no cancer)

author: @statquest
text: Corrections: 8:53 I meant to say "the remaining 198.7 people without the mutated gene". 14:27 I correctly wrote "If the tests worked as expected, 5% should have p-values less than 0.05". That is correct. However, when recording the voiceover, I said "5% should have p-values less than 0.5", which is not correct.  NOTE: In statistics, machine learning and computer programming, the default base for the log() function is 'e'. Thus, throughout this video I use the natural logarithm, or log base 'e', to do the calculations.  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @dainegai
text: Great stuff as usual :)  I was curious about the seemingly magical estimator for the standard deviation for the log(odds_ratio). Judging from the CrossValidated post here (https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/266098/how-do-i-calculate-the-standard-deviation-of-the-log-odds), this comes from assuming that the count data for each cell was drawn from a Poisson distribution. Does that sound right to you? If so, how do you "make sense" of this assumption/what it means? I usually intuitively think of a Poisson distribution as "a Binomial distribution with a whole bunch (infinite number) of trials and a super small (infinitesimal rate) of success", and I'm having trouble understanding what the "whole bunch of trials" or "super small probability of success" would mean for a cell in a two-way table.   (I'm also kind of blown away by the fact that the log(odds_ratio) is distributed Normally. From what I understand, this comes from the theory behind Generalized Linear Models, but sadly I haven't seen the part that explains why the natural parameters, e.g. log(odds_ratio) for Bernoulli response/logistic regression, ends up actually being distributed Normally. If you have any intuition/references on this, I'd appreciate them, but I don't mean to flood you with a ton of questions. And I also haven't gotten through your logistic regression videos, so maybe it's already touched upon there ;) )  Thanks again for all the great videos!

author: @Jdonovanford
text: I minute 12:32 you are dividing the data by its STD. In statistical inference one should never standardize a variable according to a sample distribution of the same data. Never. That is circular reasoning, a logical fallacy. For instance, when you estimate the significance of a correlation map, you never divide the z values by the standard deviation of the distribution of the z map. This would result in always having a proportion of significant voxels that is equal to the alpha level, regardless of the strength of the correlations.

author: @evanrushton1
text: I wrote an R script to generate the histogram alluded to by Josh at 10:00. For people following along in R this might be of use, so I figured I'd share it. Thank you for your work Dr. Starmer :bow:  # StatQuest: Odds Ratios and Log(Odds Ratios), Clearly Explained!!! Josh Starmer # Steps to reproduce the histogram for Wald's Test in R # Author: Evan Rushton # Date: 09/22/18  logOdds <- vector()  # Do this 10,000 times for (i in 1:1e4) {   # Randomly select a sample size between 300 and 400   sample_size = sample(300:400,1)   # Pick a random number between 0 and 1 for each sample   numbers = runif(sample_size,0,1)   # Numbers less than 0.08 have cancer   df <- data.frame(numbers=numbers, cancer=numbers<0.08)   # Pick another random number between 0 and 1 for each sample   df$numbers2 <- runif(sample_size,0,1)   # Numbers less than 0.39 have mutation   df$mutation <- df$numbers2<0.39   # Expected Values   exp <- df[,c("mutation","cancer")]   crossTable <- table(exp)   # Calculate Odds Ratio   cancerWith <- crossTable[4]/crossTable[2] # Odds of having cancer with mutation TRUE:TRUE / TRUE:FALSE   cancerWithout <- crossTable[3]/crossTable[1] # Odds of having cancer without mutation FALSE:TRUE / FALSE:FASLSE   oddsRatio <- cancerWith/cancerWithout   logOdds <- c(logOdds, log(oddsRatio)) }  # Create Histogram of the logOdds for the 10k samples hist(logOdds, breaks=40, xlim=c(-2,2), freq=FALSE) x <- seq(-2, 2, length=1000) curve(dnorm(x, mean=0, sd=0.43), col=4, add=TRUE)  # Observed Values df1 <- data.frame(mutation=rep(T,23), cancer=rep(T,23)) df2 <- data.frame(mutation=rep(T,117), cancer=rep(F,117)) df3 <- data.frame(mutation=rep(F,6), cancer=rep(T,6)) df4 <- data.frame(mutation=rep(F,210), cancer=rep(F,210)) obs <- rbind(df1, df2, df3, df4)  # Cross-Table obsTable <- table(obs) # Calculate Odds Ratio cancerWith <- obsTable[4]/obsTable[2] # Odds of having cancer with mutation TRUE:TRUE / TRUE:FALSE cancerWithout <- obsTable[3]/obsTable[1] # Odds of having canacer without mutation FALSE:TRUE / FALSE:FASLSE oddsRatio <- cancerWith/cancerWithout oddsRatio # 6.880342 logOdds <- log(oddsRatio) logOdds # 1.928668  # Significance Tests chisq.test(obsTable) fisher.test(obsTable)
